emails.subject: User email address enumeration vulnerability on jysk.ee
emails.bodyHtml: Hello, During our research on user account enumeration flaws on Estonian online services, we found that your website is vulnerable to the exposure of registered user email addresses. The vulnerability report is attached. We would appreciate it if you could confirm receipt of this email to prevent us from reaching out to you through other channels. Best regards, Gregor Eesmaa Computer Science MSc student University of Tartu, Institute of Computer Science

emails.subject: User email address enumeration vulnerability on jysk.ee
emails.bodyHtml: Hello, During our research on user account enumeration flaws on Estonian online services, we found that your website is vulnerable to the exposure of registered user email addresses. The vulnerability report is attached. We would appreciate it if you could confirm receipt of this email to prevent us from reaching out to you through other channels. Best regards, Gregor Eesmaa Computer Science MSc student University of Tartu, Institute of Computer Science

emails.subject: Aitäh, oleme Sinu kirja kätte saanud!
emails.bodyHtml:
Tere päevast!
Aitäh, et võtsid ühendust JYSK´i klienditeenindusega. Oleme sinu teate kätte saanud ning vastame 1-3 tööpäeva jooksul.
JYSK´i klienditeeninduse tööaeg on esmaspäevast reedeni 9.00-19.00, puhkepäevadel 9.00-17.00, telefon +372 880 1480.

Palun tutvu korduma kippuvate küsimuste jaotisega meie veebilehel www.JYSK.ee/faq

Aitäh, et valisid JYSK´i!

Võttes JYSK´iga e-posti teel ühendust, edastate oma teatud isikuandmeid. Teie e-kirjas sisalduvaid isikuandmeid kasutatakse meie õigustatud huvi alusel, et pakkuda asjakohast kliendituge ja -teenindust. Teavet selle kohta, kuidas JYSK isikuandmeid töötleb, leiate siit: JYSKi privaatsuspoliitika https://www.jysk.ee/privacy_policy, või kirjutage e-posti aadressile dpo@jysk.ee

© Copyright 2011-2025 JYSK. All rights reserved

[3W3GVV-NJ6XP]

emails.subject: FW: [JYSK Baltic ] Re: FW: User email address enumeration vulnerability on jysk.ee
emails.bodyHtml:
Dear Gregor, I confirm the receipt of your email. Thank you for providing the vulnerability report. I forwarded it to our IT department; they will look deeper into this.

 

Kind regards,

DPO JYSK Estonia

emails.subject: IKÜM taotlus seoses isikuandmete töötlemisega teenuses jysk.ee / GDPR Request Regarding Processing of Personal Data on jysk.ee
emails.bodyHtml: Lugupeetud jysk.ee vastutav andmetöötleja Pöördun, et edastada ametlikult mure isikuandmete kaitse üldmääruse (IKÜM) alusel seoses minu isikuandmete töötlemisega teenuses jysk.ee, mida pean ebaseaduslikuks ning mis võib viia nende avaldamiseni selleks volitamata isikutele ilma selge õigusliku aluseta. Manuses on ametlik taotlus, milles teostan oma õigusi IKÜM artiklite 15, 18 ja 21 alusel. Palun selle läbivaatust ja vastavate meetmete võtmist ajaraamis, mis on sätestatud IKÜM artiklis 12(3) (üks kuu taotluse saamisest). Palun teavitage taotluse kättesaamisest. Lugupidamisega Gregor Eesmaa -- Dear Data Controller of jysk.ee, I am contacting you to formally raise concerns under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) regarding what I believe to be the unlawful processing of my personal data by jysk.ee, potentially leading to its disclosure to unauthorised parties without a clear legal basis. Please find attached a formal application exercising my rights under Articles 15, 18, and 21 of the GDPR. I request that you review and act upon it accordingly, within the timeframe established by Article 12(3) of the GDPR (one month from receipt). Please confirm receipt of this request. Kind regards, Gregor Eesmaa

emails.subject: Re: IKÜM taotlus seoses isikuandmete töötlemisega teenuses jysk.ee / GDPR Request Regarding Processing of Personal Data on jysk.ee
emails.bodyHtml:
Saadan igaks juhuks ka eraldi taotluse ja aruande PDFid, mis asusid eelmise meili manuses digiallkirjastatud konteineris.

Lugupidamisega
Gregor Eesmaa

--

Just in case, providing also the request and the report PDF files, that were in the digitally signed container attached to the previous email.

Kind regards,
Gregor Eesmaa

emails.subject: RE: IKÜM taotlus seoses isikuandmete töötlemisega teenuses jysk.ee / GDPR Request Regarding Processing of Personal Data on jysk.ee
emails.bodyHtml:
Lugupeetud Gregor Eesmaa,

Kinnitame, et oleme saanud Teie 31. mai 2025. aasta päringu, mis on esitatud vastavalt Euroopa Liidu isikuandmete kaitse üldmäärusele (GDPR) ning Eesti isikuandmete kaitse seadusele.

Teie päring on edastatud meie andmekaitseametnike meeskonnale ja IT-osakonnale. Hetkel hindame ja käsitleme tõstatatud tehnilisi küsimusi, sealhulgas teatatud konto identifitseerimise võimalikku probleemi.

Töötleme Teie päringut vastavalt GDPR artiklitele 15, 18 ja 21 ning vastame määruses sätestatud ühe kuu jooksul vastavalt artiklile 12 lõige 3. Kui meil tekib vajadus täpsustuste järele või kui päringu keerukus eeldab tähtaja pikendamist, anname sellest viivitamatult teada koos vastava põhjendusega.

 

Eraldi ja väljaspool Teie ametliku päringu ulatust sooviksime küsida, kas oleksite valmis arutama meiega privaatsussõbraliku ja andmekaitsenõuetega kooskõlas oleva registreerimisprotsessi elluviimist. Arvestades Teie esitatud teabe põhjalikkust ja asjatundlikkust, usume, et Teie vaatenurk võiks aidata meil kujundada tugeva ja GDPR-iga kooskõlas oleva lähenemisviisi. Kui olete valmis oma mõtteid või soovitusi sel teemal jagama, oleksime väga tänulikud Teie panuse eest.

 

Lugupidamisega,

Jysk Linnen’n Furniture OÜ

Andmetöötlusametnik,

dpo@jysk.ee

 

 

  

Dear Gregor Eesmaa,

We confirm receipt of your request dated 31 May 2025, submitted under the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and the Estonian Personal Data Protection Act.

Your request has been forwarded to our Data Protection Officer team and IT department. We are currently evaluating and addressing the technical concerns raised, including the reported account enumeration issue.

We are processing your request in accordance with Articles 15, 18, and 21 of the GDPR and will respond within the one-month time frame established by Article 12(3). Should we require further clarification or if an extension becomes necessary due to the complexity of the request, we will notify you accordingly with a justification.

 

Separately, and outside the formal scope of your request, we would like to ask whether you would be open to consulting with us on the implementation of a privacy-compliant registration process. Given the level of detail and insight in your submission, we believe your perspective could be valuable in shaping a robust, GDPR-aligned approach. If you are willing to share your thoughts or recommendations on this matter, we would greatly appreciate your input.

 

Kind regards,

Jysk Linnen’n Furniture OÜ

Data processing officer,

dpo@jysk.ee

llmAnalysis.thinking:
**GDPR Response Analysis: My Perspective**

Alright, let's break this down. My task is to analyze this email response to a GDPR request concerning an account enumeration vulnerability. The requester has invoked Articles 15 (access), 18 (restriction), and 21 (objection) with a deadline that has clearly passed.  This email is the initial response, and it's late.  I'm treating today, 2025-08-02, as the receipt date, though the email itself is undated.

*   **Extension:** The email doesn't explicitly request an extension. It *mentions* the *possibility* of needing one due to complexity, but that's a hypothetical, not an actual request. Therefore, `extension_explicitly_requested` is `false`. There's no requested deadline or reason yet, so `extension_deadline` and `extension_reasons` are both `null`.

*   **Acknowledgement:** This is where it gets tricky.  The response acknowledges the report of an "account enumeration issue" and states they are "evaluating and addressing" it.  They aren't *denying* the issue or *agreeing* that it's a vulnerability. The wording is procedural and non-committal. Considering all the options, "unclear" best reflects their current stance. They've received the report and are assessing it, but there's no definite stance yet.

*   **Justification:** The original request wanted the legal basis under Article 6(1). The email, however, doesn't actually provide any justification for the data processing that enables account enumeration. It only confirms that *the response to the request* is being processed under the relevant articles. Thus, `justification_explicit_article6_paragraph1_points` and `justification_topics` are both `null`.

*   **Remediation:**  They say they are "evaluating and addressing" the issue and ask about a "privacy-compliant registration process". This implies something is happening, but it's clearly still in the analysis or planning phase, with no commitments for now. There's no defined plan or implementation, making both `remediation_status` and `remediation_scope` "unclear".  As there's no definite action to be taken and no timeline provided, `remediation_finish_date` is `null`.

Essentially, this is a holding response. They're acknowledging receipt and that they are looking into it but providing no firm information. This is standard GDPR practice to gather their thoughts and have time for an answer. Now I just need to compile all this information into a valid JSON object.
### Reasoning Process

1.  **Extension Request Analysis**:
    *   `extension_explicitly_requested`: The email states, "...if an extension becomes necessary due to the complexity of the request, we will notify you accordingly...". This is a conditional statement about a potential future action, not an explicit request for an extension at this time. Therefore, the value is `false`.
    *   `extension_deadline`: As no extension is requested, there is no deadline. The value is `null`.
    *   `extension_reasons`: The email mentions "complexity" as a potential future reason for an extension, but since no extension is currently being requested, this field is `null`.

2.  **Acknowledgement Analysis**:
    *   `acknowledgement`: The sender confirms receipt and states, "We are currently evaluating and addressing the technical concerns raised, including the reported account enumeration issue." They use the term "issue" (`probleemi` in Estonian), which acknowledges the user's report. However, they do not explicitly agree that it is a vulnerability or a GDPR violation, nor do they disagree. The response is a standard, non-committal holding statement. Thus, their stance is best described as `"unclear"`.

3.  **Justification for Processing Analysis (re: Art. 15)**:
    *   `justification_explicit_article6_paragraph1_points`: The original request asked for the legal basis for the processing. The response does not provide this information. It only mentions that the *request itself* is being processed under the relevant GDPR articles. Therefore, the value is `null`.
    *   `justification_topics`: The email provides no business, technical, or other reasons to justify the existence of the account enumeration functionality. The value is `null`.

4.  **Remediation Actions Analysis (re: Art. 18 & 21)**:
    *   `remediation_status`: The sender says they are "evaluating and addressing" the issue. This is vague. The separate offer to consult on a "privacy-compliant registration process" suggests they are considering changes, but no concrete plan, action, or implementation is mentioned. It is not "planned" (no plan stated), not "in_progress" (no work stated), and not "refused". The status of any remediation is therefore `"unclear"`.
    *   `remediation_scope`: Since no specific remediation actions are detailed, the scope of any potential fix is also unknown. The mention of a "privacy-compliant registration process" hints at a full fix, but it's not a commitment. The scope is `"unclear"`.
    *   `remediation_finish_date`: The email provides no timeline or deadline for resolving the issue. The only deadline mentioned is the statutory one-month period for the formal response, which has already passed. The value is `null`.

---

### Final JSON Output

emails.subject: Re: IKÜM taotlus seoses isikuandmete töötlemisega teenuses jysk.ee / GDPR Request Regarding Processing of Personal Data on jysk.ee
emails.bodyHtml:
Tere!

Tänan vastuse ja pakkumise eest!

Usun, et olen teile kõik tarviliku juba edastanud. Viitan uuesti aruandes olevale juhisele (tõlgituna):
    Vea leevendamiseks peab vastus olema ühtne nii registreeritud kui registreerimata 
meiliaadressiga. Selline ühtsus peab olema tagatud nii kasutajale kuvatud teavituses 
kui ka sellele aluseks olevas HTTP vastuses (nt staatuskoodis, päistes ja vastuse sisus)
    Näiteks, eristamatu kasutajapoolne teavitus võiks olla: "Saatsime juhised sisestatud 
meiliaadressile". Saatke meil mõlemal juhul, kuid eristage selle sisu vastavalt kasutaja
olemasolule. Näiteks uue kasutaja registreerimisel võimaldage kasutaja aktiveerimine 
ja olemasoleva kasutaja korral võimaldage parooli taastamine.
OWASP spikker: https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Authentication_Cheat_Sheet.html#account-creation

Lisaks, kui annate teada, et turvaviga on jysk.ee lehel parandatud, kontrollin selle üle.

Lisaküsimuste korral kirjutage täpsemalt.

Kõike paremat
Gregor Eesmaa

--

Hello!

Thank you for the response and for the offer!

I believe I have already given you everything necessary. I shall refer again to the guidelines in the report:
    To mitigate the flaw, the response must be uniform for both registered
and unregistered email addresses. This uniformity must apply to the message
displayed to the user as well as the underlying HTTP response details (like
status codes, headers, and body content).
    For example, the indistinguishable user-facing message could be: “We have
sent further instructions to the provided email address”. Send an email in both
cases, but differentiate the content based on account existence. For example,
for new registration, provide means for account activation, and for existing
accounts, provide means for account recovery.
OWASP cheat sheet: https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Authentication_Cheat_Sheet.html#account-creation

Additionally, when you let me know the vulnerability is fixed on jysk.ee, I will reassess it.

In case of additional questions, please ask in more details.

Best wishes
Gregor Eesmaa

emails.subject: RE: IKÜM taotlus seoses isikuandmete töötlemisega teenuses jysk.ee / GDPR Request Regarding Processing of Personal Data on jysk.ee
emails.bodyHtml:
Lugupeetud G. Eesmaa

Leiate manusest meie ametliku vastuse Teie hiljutisele päringule.

 

Palume vabandust, et meie vastus on hetkel saadaval ainult inglise keeles. Eesti keelne versioon edastatakse 1–2 tööpäeva jooksul

 

Kui Teil on küsimusi või vajate täiendavat selgitust, võtke meiega julgelt ühendust.

 

Lugupidamisega,

JYSK DPO (andmekaitseametnik)

 

……………………………………………………………………………………………………………

 

Dear G. Eesmaa,

Please find attached our formal response to your recent request.

 

We sincerely apologize that our response is currently available only in English. The Estonian version will be provided within 1–2 business days.

Should you have any questions or require further clarification, please feel free to contact us.



Kind regards,
JYSK DPO (Data Protection Officer)

llmAnalysis.thinking:
**My Analysis of JYSK's GDPR Response**

Alright, let's break this down. My goal is to extract the relevant information from this JYSK email and PDF response concerning a GDPR request related to an account enumeration vulnerability. I need to clearly define the situation for each field.

First, the extension. Based on the email date (2025-06-30), assuming the original request was around 2025-06-02 to give them a month, they responded within the allowed timeframe. No extension was requested, so `extension_explicitly_requested` is `false`, and the related fields (`extension_deadline`, `extension_reasons`) are `null`.

Next, the acknowledgment. Despite attempts to downplay the issue, JYSK's language ("working on introducing necessary changes," "revised the mechanism") clearly indicates they agree with the core problem – that account enumeration is possible. The "agree" value seems the most appropriate here, even with the caveats about market practice.

Now, for the justification under Article 6 of the GDPR. They directly cite Article 6(1)(f) ("legitimate interest"), so `justification_explicit_article6_paragraph1_points` will be `["f"]`. The justification topics are a bit more nuanced. They mention account security, preventing abuse, facilitating user support (account management), user experience (preventing registration mistakes), and that it's "common and established market practice." So the array of topics will be `["account_security", "user_experience", "widespread_practice", "account_management"]`.

Finally, the remediation. The email states they are "working on introducing necessary changes" and has a completion date of 2025-09-30.  This tells me the work is in progress. They haven't *completed* the fix yet. "Now revised the mechanism" could be read as both, however it is not deployed. The scope is full. They are providing a uniform response, eliminating the possibility.  They clearly give a specific date: `2025-09-30`. So, `remediation_status` is `"in_progress"`, `remediation_scope` is `"full"`, and `remediation_finish_date` is `"2025-09-30"`.

Therefore, the final output will reflect these analyses to ensure it is accurate and clearly describes this scenario. I will now compile the JSON object based on this breakdown.
An analysis of the provided email and its attachment leads to the following conclusions for each field in the required JSON schema.

### Reasoning

1.  **Extension Request**: The response is dated 2025-06-30. Given the request was sent "previously" and today is 2025-08-02, the response was sent within the statutory one-month period. There is no language requesting an extension.
    *   `extension_explicitly_requested`: `false`
    *   `extension_deadline`: `null`
    *   `extension_reasons`: `null`

2.  **`acknowledgement`**: JYSK's response confirms they have "reviewed the relevant functionality and now working on introducing necessary changes to ensure that the user experience does not allow third parties to infer whether a particular email address is associated with a Jysk account." They also state that this change will "eliminate even the theoretical possibility of account enumeration". This constitutes a clear agreement with the substance of the vulnerability report.
    *   `acknowledgement`: `"agree"`

3.  **Justification for Processing**: The response provides a detailed justification for the previous system behavior.
    *   `justification_explicit_article6_paragraph1_points`: The text explicitly states the processing "was based on Jysk’s legitimate interest" and later refers directly to the "balancing test required under GDPR Article 6(1)(f)". This directly cites point 'f'.
    *   `justification_topics`: Several business reasons are given:
        *   "ensuring user account security, preventing abuse" -> `account_security`
        *   "facilitating efficient user support" -> `account_management`
        *   "enabled users to identify potential registration mistakes... preventing unnecessary duplication or confusion" -> `user_experience`
        *   "It is a common and established market practice" -> `widespread_practice`

4.  **Remediation Actions**: The response outlines the planned corrective measures.
    *   `remediation_status`: The email states they are "now working on introducing necessary changes". This indicates the work has started but is not yet complete, making the status `"in_progress"`.
    *   `remediation_scope`: The fix is described as creating a "uniform response to both new and existing users" that "eliminates even the theoretical possibility of account enumeration". This is a comprehensive fix, not a partial mitigation. Therefore, the scope is `"full"`.
    *   `remediation_finish_date`: The response provides a specific deadline: "It is planned that changes will be completed and implemented by 30.09.2025."

This detailed analysis results in the following JSON object.
